deliverables/train/openstack-ansible.yam.message:
Not sure what's `Bump SHAs for stable/train` [1] but it seems to introduced some sort of new feature into a stable branch.

```
features:
  - |
    Get ceph keyrings from files, if variable``ceph_keyrings_dir`` is defined
    the keyrings will be extracted from files. All files in the directory
    must have ``.keyring`` extention and be named with its corresponding
    ``ceph_client`` name. For example, if ``cinder_ceph_client`` is ``cinder``
    the cinder keyring file must be named ``cinder.keyring``.
    Each file must contain username and the key and nothing more, below
    an example for cinder.keyring content.
    .. code-block:: text
    [client.cinder]
    key = XXXXXXXXXXX
```

Introduce new features on stable branches is something that we want to avoid, however openstack-ansible don't seem to follow the stable branch policy [2][3], so I think we can go further with these changes.

Hence if these changes really introduced a new feature then we should release a minore version (20.1.0 rather than 20.0.3).

Thoughts?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/0fcb0af4dff169997948a778c3a170f7fe84ced7
[2] https://github.com/openstack/governance/blob/master/reference/projects.yaml#L2154,L2258
[3] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/tags/stable_follows-policy.html

README.md.message:
Hmm, I am not sure this list is useful in the hacluster readme. It is also not complete. We might want to keep:
"The principle charm must have explicit support for the hacluster interface
in order for clustering to occur - otherwise nothing actually get configured." or something like it instead.

It's useful because people won't have to troll through every charm to find out if they can use the hacluster charm.

There may well be non-supported charms that are not in the list. Is that what you mean or have I missed supported ones?

The point is the list is not maintainable as evidenced by the fact that it is missing a number of API charms like: designate, aodh, gnocchi .... and more.
So my argument is to point to what indicates a principle charm supports this relationship rather than trying to maintain a list here.
A major hint is if the principle charm requires an interface "ha" in its metadata.yaml.

For the Virtual IP method of implementing HA ...

We need to convey this is different from DNS HA above.
Ok, I thought that "a VIP" was in contrast to DNS HA.
It is, but the language above does not make that clear.
I think we still need to make clear that VIP vs DNS HA are mutually exclusive. Even if we refer out to the deploy guide.
Ok.
Do we want this in the REAME until the appendix is available?
That was my intention. It was a convenient help as I am working on both. I will remove it.
We may want to keep some of the original verbiage to explain *why* cluster_count is necessary not just that it is best practice.
Ok. I just felt it sounded "bad" to say that race conditions may exist.
It is helpful for us supporting the charm to point to documentation that says please set this value for these reasons. Otherwise, we get lots of bugs where we have to repeat this over and over.

We may need to keep the original resource configuration section or move that content to the interface-hacluster readme with a link to that here.
It is valuable information that should not be lost.
Ok, I misunderstood our irc convo. I came away with the understanding that this content was of no value anymore.
This is true, as I mentioned, if we keep the documentation in the interface-hacluster that is acceptable. Looks like we do so we can drop this point.

I think the doc strings of interface-hacluster (for example https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-interface-hacluster/src/branch/master/common.py ) supersede this charm author section so I'm +1 on dropping it
We mostly want to point people to use the interface-hacluster which implements all of this. It is useful information though, that I would not want to lose.
Can we at least add "mutually exclusive"?
Sure thing.

I still think we need some of the original language:

"The clustered nodes must have static or "reserved" IP addresses registered in MAAS. If using a version of MAAS earlier than 2.3 the DNS hostname(s) should be pre-registered in MAAS before use with DNS HA."
Ok.

This service also needs a mysql/maria/something database. Currently we use an external trove db and feed credentials for that into the service config. In order to test this service properly in the run job we'll need a db of some sort. With gitea we run that locally via docker as well.

Maybe we should take this as an opportunity to go back to running the database alongside the service on the same host? THat will make db updates simpler/easier as well as testing. Then we can take a reasonable outage and migrate the db over and call it a day.

Related, we'll want to add database backups to this new service setup (gitea has examples of doing this with docker composed things).

cyborg/api/controllers/base.py.message: Put these packages under third-party software libraries, maybe it should in line28, and add a blank line between the third-party software libraries and Cyborg's libraries.

As we discussed in IRC meeting, the community agreed to support microversion firstly, and them have another bp and implementation of schema check. 
IRC meeting log: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/openstack_cyborg/2020/openstack_cyborg.2020-02-27-03.00.log.html#l-29

At [1], I would like you can changes it's define name, how about "current_api" or "current_api_version"?

[1]https://review.opendev.org/#/c/696860/5/cyborg/api/controllers/v2/__init__.py@121

Why are you need these?

I think we dont need these minimum and maximum version, if the user request 'OpenStack-API-Version': '2.0' we just should check whether it can be accessable, if yes, return 'OpenStack-API-Version' in response header with the expected result, otherwise raise Error with some messages.

So I think 'OpenStack-API-Minimum-Version' and 'OpenStack-API-Maximum-Version' should not be defined.

root@ubuntu-OpenStack:/opt/stack/cyborg# curl -g -i -X GET http://localhost/accelerator/devices -s -H "$CTYPE" -H "$AUTH" -H "O-API-Version: accelerator 2.0"
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Tue, 17 Mar 2020 03:11:30 GMT
Server: Apache/2.4.29 (Ubuntu)
Vary: OpenStack-API-Version
OpenStack-API-Minimum-Version: 2.0
OpenStack-API-Maximum-Version: 2.0
OpenStack-API-Version: 2.0
Content-Length: 15
Content-Type: application/json
x-openstack-request-id: req-3826242d-ef82-4d89-9756-7628ec94961a
Connection: close

Looks good, it's ok keeps "OpenStack-API-Minimum-Version" and "OpenStack-API-Maximum-Version" in response.

which version would want to use as default? '2.0'? or 'latest'?

I suggest use "2.0", when we check the UT/FT, that we can use latest version inherit the base test case.

I think you should add a global parameter of the default api version to match the request in header:

such as:

# The default api version request if none is requested in the headers
DEFAULT_API_VERSION = "2.0"

nits: As microversion grows, it seems more appropriate to start with "2.1" than "2.0", "1~10,11~20" rather than "0~9,10~19", but in general the difference is not significant.
A suggestion inline, in order to increase the user's readability, we can write comments on the variable definition in the subsequent programming.

This one should become "tls_ciphers-optional" and we should add one that is not optional (required: true).

fail:
  msg: "..."

should be fine I think. But why must we run it as non-root, when we can run it as root on c7?
ok, i actually thought that based on the initial comments, that it doesn't work at all.  IMHO, i think we should drop this "workaround" here...

Or at least make it conditional?
If role is supposed to install podman, it should install it, whatever OS it runs on. If you don't want to install podman on CentOS-7, don't run this role..?
I have no problem with that but what about that poor soul that will try to run them on centos-7 and fail? Maybe I will only keep a comment near the validation, so others will know what/why.

i'm a little torn about this one.  what we really need to validate is if podman works at all, not if specific features of it work?  i'd be inclined to just add become: true to the podman version etc, otherwise, perhaps we should actually just do the podman ps as with become: false inside our tests (not the actual role) for all platforms except c7.. on the other hand, this means differnent behaviour per OS.. i don't know, i'm torn.  i'd like comments from others.

Happy to correct, the reason why I added this is because I had cases where only one of the 3 commands failed, running all provides a much better level of confidence that the required services are usable.

The only thing better than this would be even run an alpine container in order to validate that the system can really start containers.

I think we need to validate here if podman is installed, if this role is called "install-podman". So, "podman ps" seems redundant. It already checks if podman can run, this is not purpose of this role AFAIU. Please correct me if I'm wrong.
this is completely redundant here
Done

These commands are actually checking if podman can run without any other settings applied, and this is not a purpose of this role. It should check only if podman is installed.

For example in some platforms, you'll need to tweak an operation system to make podman working. This task just will fail for these platforms while it shouldn't.
Done
yes, it's exactly what I meant

roles/install-podman/tasks/main.yaml.message:
This role is usually used at the very beginning of a node deployment, in pre-runs.
When pre runs fail they are attempted three times, before bailing out.
If this validation is not performed, user will realize after some time in the run play.
If it's performed, it will take some time anyway to report failure.
I consider this as a runtime check, It could also be a test time check, but we would need to add tests to verify, and then understand what could be different at runtime and what could cause this to fail.
Either way a check is needed, because it makes very clear what failed. Maybe an impact evaluation could bring some answer on its best position.
why? I do not see any linter asking me to do so.

Sure, I'll explain. It can't be caught by linters, but when boolean variable is passed to playbook run it can be interpreted as string if not using "|bool". It's a good practice to add "bool" filter to all boolean variables. This is well documented in Ansible docs:

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_conditionals.html#the-when-statement

> Variables defined in the playbooks or inventory can also be used, just make sure to apply the |bool filter to non boolean variables (ex: string variables with content like ‘yes’, ‘on’, ‘1’, ‘true’). An example may be the execution of a task based on a variable’s boolean value:
why not "command"? there are no any shell specific things
Because command does run a single command, not a series of commands. Any more nitpicks?
+1 for using a loop with command.

I literally called this "nit" :) There is "loop" command in ansible that can help with running a few commands: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_loops.html
But it's not must at all, just a good practice to use command when it's possible.

gbpservice/neutron/plugins/ml2plus/drive.message:
This hard-code tenant_name cannot be correct. Should it be l3out.tenant_name?

But if an L3Outside has been passed in, why is it being copied here? Can't it just be used as-is in the following line?
Comments that aren't at the end of a line of code should be made up of complete sentences, with capitalization and punctuation. This needs a period.

Just matching on vrf_name seems like it might find L3Outsides that reference VRFs that have the same name but have a different tenant_name. I think you need to first figure out whether a VRF with L3Outside's tenant_name exists. If it does, pass that tenant_name to this find, and if not, pass 'common'.

First, this method no longer performs a DB query, so the name is misleading, and the aim_ctx param is not used.

Second, the method isn't needed since you could replace the call to this method on line 372 with a simple python statement:

used_ids = netaddr.IPSet([n.router_id for n in aim_l3out_nodes])
Nit: Comments that aren't on the same line as code should be proper sentences, so this needs a period.

All of this could be simplified to:

        vrf = self.aim.get(aim_ctx, aim_resource.VRF(
                               tenant_name=aim_l3out.tenant_name,
                               name=aim_l3out.vrf_name))
        if (not vrf and
            aim_l3out.tenant_name != COMMON_TENANT_NAME):
            vrf = self.aim.get(aim_ctx, aim_resource.VRF(
                                   tenant_name=COMMON_TENANT_NAME,
                                   name=aim_l3out.vrf_name))

Also, I'm not sure the indenting is 100% correct. When a function's args don't all fit on the same line, I generally find the code is most readable with the newline immediately after the '(' of the function call, and the first arg indended 4 spaces relative to the start of the function all. This avoids pushing everything that follows too far to the right. For the first call, this style would look something like:

vrf = self.aim.get(
    aim_ctx, aim_resource.VRF(
        tenant_name=aim_l3out.tenant_name,
        name=aim_l3out.vrf_name))

The last two lines about might fit on one line, and definitely would if you named the param 'l3out' instead of 'aim_l3out':

vrf = self.aim.get(
    aim_ctx, aim_resource.VRF(
        tenant_name=l3out.tenant_name, name=l3out.vrf_name))

The proposed code avoids the extra assignment of vrf = None, but the original code makes the selection choice described in the comment a bit clearer imho. I'm fine either way, but just wanted to point this out.

ironic/conductor/base_manager.py.message:
In theory, do we really need to?

With deploy steps, we ultimately have better granularity to where a deploy is, and the next heartbeat would trigger the same action, so could it not be okay to just let the node not move?

Also, if a node is in maintenance, _should_ we actually change it?

We actually patched this downstream, because we want to move nodes (even in maintenance) from cleaning to cleanfail, if it times out. This is why I was looking at the code here: it doesn't quite make sense, so I'd like to clean it up.

- If folks are specifying the maintenance value in the filter, it seems like we should honour that. If they aren't specifying maintenance in the filter, then we shouldn't be blocking/assuming we know best here.

- if we think we should always block and not do anything if a node is in maintenance, then we should add a comment about that and remove the maintenance stuff from all the filters.

Regardless of what we do, I'll still need to patch downstream unless we add some sort of config upstream to allow nodes-in-maintenance to be failed. But at least this code will be more understandable. (eg, I removed maintenance=False from the filter in the periodic task for cleaning timeout and it didn't work because of this code.)

Also, given that some code calls this method without setting maintenance to False, I wonder if they callers meant to operate on all nodes. Eg I think we need to handle nodes-in-maintenance here, otherwise they won't be associated with the correct conductor, but I could be wrong: https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/8294afa6231629f9734f19ea5b3b0253ee9b8957/ironic/conductor/base_manager.py#L235

Recall: this is a generic method, it shouldn't know whether it is dealing with deploy steps or anything else.

ironic/conductor/base_manager.py.message: I picked up on one fine detail, that we're actually checking desired state in the state when the periodic fired. With that I think I'm good with this.

> Recall: this is a generic method, it shouldn't know whether it is
 > dealing with deploy steps or anything else.

I agree with ruby on this. This is a generic method and it shouldn't care if the node is in maintenance or not. It should handle both depending on the caller. The caller of this method should decide whether to include nodes in maintenance or not.

neutron_tempest_plugin/api/test_security.message:
depends on the order of the tests we can get quota to be 2^31 in the beginning of the "test_sg_rules_quota_increased" test. So we need to specify some kind of cleanup by the end of each test. I would say that we need to do that for both: quota and rules. The following examples may help:
BaseSecGroupQuota._set_sg_quota
BaseSecGroupQuota._create_security_groups

Indeed it could be problematic, this case could break test_sg_rules_quata_values if the update there happens and the creation of new rules begins and after that the update in this test changes value to the smaller number. In this situation the previous test will fail. Need to run several times gates to see if it happens.
Anyway I don't understand how cleanup can help in this situation. And I don't understand what this cleanup should do, change value to what?

As per documentation [1] all the tests from one class are executed one by one and not in parallel. And as far as I know tenant is created for each test class. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/write_tests.html#adding-a-new-testcase

We had the same situation in kuryr-tempest-plugin, so we used  @lockutils.synchronized decorator.
You can take a look in kuryr-tempest-plugin/kuryr_tempest_plugin/tests/scenario/test_port_pool.py

The question is do you really want it. If statistically the problem doesn't occur (my understanding is that it doesn't) maybe you can go with this solution and check the alternatives when the test will start failing

Ok. You are correct. It can happen if you will remove or change the "group_regex" in the stestr configuration file. By default it has "([^\.]*\.)*" so the "config_file.py" [1] creates a method to group all tests by the class name. Each group is executed by it's worker so all the tests within one class are serialized.

So I don't think that lockutils is required here as all our tests are executed with the default regex.

[1] https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/blob/master/stestr/config_file.py#L156

That is true, those tests can have impact on each other. And cleanup after test may not help also as in corner case both tests can be run in parallel and this one will set quota to 2^31 and the other one will want to double it in same time.
IMO the only solution for that would be to use different tenants in each of those tests.
In the example I provided all the tests reside under the same class and they run in parallel, so I am not sure we can count on this documentation, but I am not 100% sure in this case
I would add cleanup call for the _create_max_allowed_sg_rules_amount method too. It is not critical in this particular case but might be critical in any further

if the tests run in parallel it doesn't solve the problem we were talking about.
If not you are returning to the default value after each iteration. Maybe it's better to do it only once when you finish the test_sg_rules_quota_values (once again only in case tests do not run in parallel)

as we discussed in the irc with Eran, tests from one class will not be run in parallel so it should be good.
You're right that there will be all cleanups added but still IMHO it's making test to be longer then needed and that is not necessary :)

I do agree with you that test will take more time. From my point of view this is just the most transparent way to revert changes back. As the second option I can see is to add cleanup in the beginning of each test but if someone will write a new test he/she needs to keep that in mind.
Invoke cleanup from the setup (test level) method has the disadvantage too as we don't know if there will be any changes in each test so we can initiate excess API call (or several - for each resource type).

I agree that You should get original amount of sg in setUp method or at the begin of the test, so between L304 and 305 and add cleanup there.
Now it's as Genadi said - You will always end with cleanup which will set value from the previous iteration, not what was originally set.

There will be cleanup for each _set_sg_rules_quota iteration but in the reverse order (stack). So in the end of the test there will be the same value as it was before the test has been started.
It will not solve the issue with the parallel execution but we shouldn't face the parallel execution if we will configure the tempest run correctly.
its not  you are right, added by mistake

You need to add this cleanup between L301 and L302.
Now, if for any reason assertion in L306 will fail, You will never reach to this point to add and do this cleanup.

ironic/drivers/modules/network/neutron.p.message:
So I feel like just pulling the client for doing the entire plug op is the wrong thing to do.

Reason being, if a user attempts to plug a network, we don't exactly know if the vif is in their rights to plug. Really, only a connection with their credentials can determine that. The need for the admin credentials though is to update the mac address of the port, so I think we need to explictly break that out as a specific action where we use elevated access and then allow port binding to continue with the user's context.
Ah, that makes perfect sense. I'll update the patch!

specs/xwiki-farm.rst.message: As this seems to be the main topic requiring resources in the current installation, can we have more information about what xwiki provides here that will make moderation easier?

I'll add reference to:

https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/AdminGuide/AntiSpam

in next patchset
From the linked doc, I don't see how this is better than nested pages in mediawiki, could you expand on this?

I found it simpler (read: more user-friendly) to get specific groups in charge of maintaining specific pages, with inheritance of access rights by default.

It also has a navigation widget where you can exclude/include specific pages, making it easier to emerge reference information.

All those things are possible with mediawiki, but they are more bolted on the original use case (which is wikipedia "everyone-can-update-everything in a flat space" use case), which explains why it never took for wiki.o.o.

I'll add details on new patchset.

I'm still not convinced that this holds true. I think we should make running our own installation a first priority and only if that turns out to be a major effort consider taking up an external hosting offer.

No, I'm not volunteering. I'm wondering though who the various "we"'s are. If there is a community that needs a wiki, where is their contribution to e.g. OpenDev enabling us to make this happen? What prevents them from using the existing wiki solution we have? 

Also, why does this have to happen under the OpenDev umbrella? They could just use the xwiki.com offer under their own power and maybe if it turns out to be successful, we could adopt this approach later after evaluating it.

Well... Are you volunteering to set up and administer a xwiki farm tomorrow? My impression was that we were already overloaded maintaining the services that we committed to running ourselves, with nobody with free time to solve the "wiki situation".

I'm suggesting we run a proof-of-concept based on the hosted offer. We have a community (the Open Infra Labs initiative) needing a wiki ASAP. I'd hate to have them use some proprietary service somewhere while we look for volunteers to run our own installation. The hosted offer will allow to immediately evaluate xwiki without committing too many resources.

We'll definitely have another discussion once the evaluation is over before we consider expanding the setup to other communities.

Re: community needing a wiki: the OSF is helping bootstrapping the OpenInfra labs community (formerly known as Massachussets Open Cloud), a community of practice around operating OpenStack clouds for academic networks. That community is interested in using Opendev for project infrastructure, including Gerrit for amnaging code repositories. At those early stages they need a mailing-list (already set up at lists.opendev.org) and a wiki to share information.

Yes we could ask them to set themselves up outside of Opendev, but (1) that would not be very welcoming (2) we would pass on the opportunity to use it to evaluate Xwiki wikifarm for Opendev.

Personally I think we should default to experimenting and doing things (especially if they do not require that much of our own resources) rather than not doing.

The main reason not to use the existing wiki is that it's the OpenStack wiki, and we'd previously drawn the line that we didn't want to end up responsible for running that as part of OpenDev. What's compelling about starting with a hosted Xwiki is that we're not on the hook for working out deployment and systems maintenance for it but can move the content and domain name to a server we run later if that ends up being something we have volunteers to take on.

After doing some more investigation on etcd upgrades, I think we will have to version /opt/etcd. This is to handle cases where our platform upgrade includes a new version of etcd. In those cases, once the new version of etcd runs with the old etcd data, it upversions it and it is no longer possible to run the old version of etcd against it. To support rollbacks after upgrading controller-1 to release N+1, I think we need to keep the release N version of the etcd data intact.

The migration of the etcd data will just be a direct copy of the files. This needs to be done at a time where we can avoid losing any data, so either after the etcd has stopped on controller-0 (prior to swacting to the upgraded controller-1) or before etcd has started on controller-1 (after swacting).
I would move this to the work items section - having it here makes it sound like it is being done as part of the "system upgrade-start" command.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Monitor imports module which uses eventlet. Can you please clarify what means "monitor does not use eventlet"? I'm a bit confused. What needs to be done to enable monitor to use it?

"keepalived_state_change" is an independent process spawned by the L3 agent. This process uses threading instead of eventlet because:
- The number of threads created is very small
- We don't need to deal with the problem of thread starvation if the thread explicitly do not release the GIL. We just rely on the Python thread preemption to swap between them.

Not sure I understand why this is not working.
"Eventlet is thread-safe and can be used in conjunction with normal Python threads" - https://eventlet.net/doc/threading.html
Always a pleasure.
Fair enough, thanks for detailed answer! Sorry for bothering you so much, just wanted to get to the root of this eventlet issue, as you said it might not be the only place where it happens..

Could be another option but I never tested it. Because of how the monitor is implemented, I prefer threading rather than eventlets. The cost of using threading is minimal for one single short thread (arping is executed 3 times, that means more or less 3 seconds).

For sure, evenlet can be used with threads.

The problem we have here is that, when the eventlet thread is created [1], remains halted until the eventlet "main" thread (there is no such concept, this is the caller thread only) returns the GIL and the eventlet executor starts running it.

But this never happens because the main thread never returns the GIL, for example, by calling eventlet.sleep. You can see that executing the modified functional test locally and changing the log file to a static one, for example "/tmp/log_arping". Tail this file while executing the test case and change the execution mode (eventlet or threads). You'll see in the second case how the arping is sent and logged in the file.

eventlets are very useful but very "frail" if the code implementation is not correct. Seeing this problem I'm wondering if this problem is happening in other sections of the code.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/b56815113dbf60671ce8eefdd329230b393a8652/neutron/agent/linux/ip_lib.py#L1070

"keepalived_state_change" has two blocking threads running in "parallel": the one monitoring any IP change and the other one reading the queue populated by the monitor.

The first one uses a blocking method from Pyroute:

_ip = privileged.get_iproute(namespace
_ip.bind(async_cache=True)
_ip.get() <-- this method does not return until there is a change

Because of this, we can't use eventlets in "keepalived_state_change", because when this thread never releases the GIL.

We need to have this _ip.get() in an endless loop because any event happened outside the execution of this method is skipped (we can miss an IP change).

That means the second thread in the monitor, the one reading the IP addresses stored in the queue by the first thread, needs somehow to be executed apart from the first one. That's why I implemented the "keepalived_state_change" using threading instead of eventlets, because Python threads are preemptive and will allow the second thread to be executed. Because the second thread is most of the time idle, it will return quickly the GIL to the first one.
And probably doing sleep(0) after spawning the greenthread :)

Ah, got it, thanks very much for the clarification.
So another option would be to follow https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/contributor/internals/services_and_agents.html#interacting-with-eventlet for state_change_monitor, right (since it's a "service using eventlet")?

tripleo_common/utils/config.py.message:
Though this would work, should we be more explicit to keep it as 'service_extra_vars' key in  'role_group_vars' and then allow only that to override role['config'], finally deleting 'service_extra_vars' from 'role_group_vars'?

Ignore if it would be more confusing.
why would we do that? It would work too, but unless there is a reason, i would keep it as simple.

Though not a big reason....

We're updating role[config] with everything in role_group_vars[role_name] and when we assign it to role_group_vars in the next line they refer to the same exact dict object. Though role[config] has no significance beyond this, changing one would change the other. Also, roledata would be modified as well.

AFAIU, the vars in {{role.name}}ExtraGroupVars are _only_ supposed to override service specific vars, so I thought about being explicit.

I believe RoleExtraGroupVars should override any ansible var because of the way it's loaded.  I think this is a difference between the ansible/hiera implementation only because we're using ansible as the deployment mechanism too rather than just configs.  From an flexibility standpoint I think this makes this more useful for folks who need to tweak things on a role level.
